The remainder of this paper is organized as follows.
SectionÂ 2 first introduces the background of this paper.
Then we propose BLADE-FL in SectionÂ 3, and optimize the upper bound on the loss function in SectionÂ 4.
Section 5 investigates the issue of lazy clients.
Section 6 discusses the privacy issue.
The experimental results are presented in SectionÂ 7.
SectionÂ 8 concludes this paper.
In addition, TableÂ I lists the main notations used in this paper.

Fig.Â 4 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î±ğ›¼\alphaÂ (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while TableÂ II shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. Here, we set Î²=6ğ›½6\beta=6. First, Fig.Â 4(a) shows that larger Î±ğ›¼\alpha leads to larger loss function. This is due to the fact that both Kğ¾K and Ï„ğœ\tau from (3) drops as Î±ğ›¼\alpha grows.
Second, from TableÂ II, the longer a training iteration consumes, the more training time each client takes. For example, using MNIST, the training time increases from 404040 to 646464 as Î±ğ›¼\alpha rises from 111 to 555. This observation is consistent with Corollary 1.

Fig.Â 5 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î²ğ›½\betaÂ (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while TableÂ III shows the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.

Fig.Â 6 shows the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Nğ‘N, while TableÂ IV illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.
We set Î²=6ğ›½6\beta=6. First, from TableÂ IV, we notice that the optimal mining time drops as Nğ‘N increases, which is consistent with Proposition 3. For example, using MNIST, Î²â€‹Kâˆ—ğ›½superscriptğ¾\beta K^{*} drops from 707070 to 505050 as Nğ‘N rises from 101010 to 252525.
Second, from Fig.Â 6(a), larger Nğ‘N leads to lower loss function. This is because the involved datasets are larger as Nğ‘N grows, which causes a smaller loss function. Third, from both Fig.Â 6(a) and (b), Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} approaches a fixed value when Nğ‘N is sufficiently large (e.g., N>20ğ‘20N>20). This observation is in line with Corollary 3.

Fig.Â 7 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î·ğœ‚\eta, while TableÂ V illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.
First, from TableÂ V, we find that the optimal mining time rises as Î·ğœ‚\eta grows, which is in line with Corollary 4. For example, using MNIST, Î²â€‹Kâˆ—ğ›½superscriptğ¾\beta K^{*} rises from 545454 to 727272 as Î·ğœ‚\eta grows from 0.0050.0050.005 to 0.10.10.1. This is because Î·ğœ‚\eta grows significantly when Î·â€‹L<1ğœ‚ğ¿1\eta L<1, and our developed upper bound is no longer suitable. For example, when Î·>0.05ğœ‚0.05\eta>0.05, the loss function increases as Î·ğœ‚\eta rises in our experiments for both MNIST and Fashion-MNIST.

Fig.Â 8 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of lazy ratio MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N}, while TableÂ VI shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. We set the power of artificial noise Ïƒ2=0.01superscriptğœ20.01\sigma^{2}=0.01.
First, from TableÂ VI, it is observed the optimal training time steps up as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} increases. For example, using MNIST, the time allocated to training rises from 303030 to 505050 as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} increases from 0%percent00\% to 30%percent3030\%. This observation is consistent with Corollary 5.
Second, from Fig.Â 8(a), the learning performance degrades as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} grows. This is because more lazy clients involved in the system as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} grows, leading to lower training efficiency.
